title: Frances Lin

üì£ Seeking opportunities in data science, machine learning, or AI roles starting in December 2025 or later!

I am a PhD candidate in Statistics at Oregon State University. I am currently a Software Engineer Intern at Posit Software, PBC (formerly RStudio Inc.).
Outside of work, I enjoy skiing, traveling, being outdoors, and watching thriller or dark comedy films and series on Netflix.

title: Experience
text:
Oregon State University

Doctoral Researcher
Sep 2021 - Present


Statistics / ML Consultant
Jan 2021 - Mar 2025
‚Ä¢ Provided consulting services across diverse fields, collaborating with faculty members, junior statisticians, and client researchers to support multiple PhD and master‚Äôs-level research initiatives.  ‚Ä¢ Effectively communicated statistical concepts to non-statistical clients and delivered in-depth reports on topics including simple statistical tests, advanced data modeling, application software (R, Python), experimental design, and data processing and visualization.


Graduate Teaching Assistant
Mar 2020 - Present
‚Ä¢ Assist with graduate and undergraduate courses such as machine learning III, missing data and causal inference, spatial statistics, stochastic models, computational statistics, data analysis methods I (hypothesis testing, multiple testing), II (regression analysis, model selection), III (dimension reduction techniques, generalized regression models), mathematical statistics I, II, statistical methods, statistics for engineers, and elementary statistics I.  ‚Ä¢ Teach R programming and discuss statistical problems during labs or recitations, hold office hours, and grade exams and assignments.


Graduate Project Assistant
Jun 2024 - Aug 2024
‚Ä¢ Assisted with the design and development of the course curriculum for spatial statistics.  ‚Ä¢ Applied a variety of spatial models, including kriging / Gaussian process regression, C / SAR (conditional / simultaneous autoregressive), and Poisson process / CSR models for simulation and applications such as housing price prediction, disease risk mapping, and forest and forest fire modeling.

title: About
text:
Thanks for visiting my site!
I am a PhD candidate in Statistics at Oregon State University. Broadly speaking, my research interests lie in
for large and complex time series data, with applications to energy forecasting and claims prediction. My other interests include deep learning and its more flexible and explainable probabilistic variant models (e.g., deep Gaussian processes, deep Gaussian Markov Random Fields) for space and space-time modeling.

title: Portfolio
text: No matching items

title: About
text:
PhD
For my PhD dissertation, advised by Dr.¬†Lisa Madsen and Dr.¬†Charlotte Wickham (now at Posit Software, PBC), I focus on the Markov MTD (Mixture Transition Distribution) models and the Bayesian NNMP (Nearest-Neighbor Mixture Process) models for time series forecasting and spatial prediction, as developed by Zheng et al.¬†and presented in [1], [2], and [3]. To achieve robust, flexible, and scalable modeling of time series and spatial data, both the MTD and NNMP models utilize probabilistic graphical model (DAG or Bayesian network) representations, finite mixture model structures, Bayesian hierarchical model formations, and MCMC algorithms.
My specific contributions include incorporating the copulas in the MTD model to capture more complex and flexible dependence structures; extending the MTD model to handle zero-inflated positively-skewed data; validating the models and assessing model performance through simulations and real-world data applications; developing a software package for the proposed models (using R, C++); and comparing the proposed models with other benchmark approaches, such as LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks (using PyTorch), to ensure robustness and accuracy.

title: About
text:
Master‚Äôs
For my Master‚Äôs capstone project, advised by Dr.¬†James Molyneux, I worked on selected spatial and temporal point processes leading up to Hawkes processes (or self-exciting point processes), which find applications in fields such as seismology, criminology, risk management, finance, etc.

title: A Great Summer of Dev, Data, and Deploy at Posit
text:
The Journey So Far

filtro


tidymodels

title: A Great Summer of Dev, Data, and Deploy at Posit
text:
Behind the Curtain

PR #1: All the Things, All at Once
Week 1-2
My first few weeks at Posit have been packed with learning and collaboration. I‚Äôve had daily meetings with Max (Max Kuhn) and Emil (Emil Hvitfeldt). Max brings deep expertise in modeling and machine learning, while Emil is highly knowledgeable about software development, from Git, GitHub, and GitHub Actions CI/CD (nasty stuff!) to Positron (a VS Code‚Äìlike IDE), and R‚Äôs S3 object-oriented programming (OOP). 1
It‚Äôs tempting to jump straight into coding and testing, but Max emphasized an important lesson: before writing any code, it‚Äôs crucial to step back and think through the software design ‚Äî often, the real challenge lies in the methodology, not just the implementation. Meanwhile, Emil and I did some pair programming (my first time!), which led to two great learning sessions:

‚ÄúEverything Positron‚Äù 2 
‚ÄúEverything S3 OOP‚Äù.



S3 OOP Brush-Up
Week 1-4
To be completely honest, while Xiaotian (Xiaotian Zheng)‚Äôs {mtd} 3 package is quite well-organized ‚Äî and I would argue that the most challenging aspect of extending it lies more in model development than in software engineering ‚Äî I have little to no experience with R‚Äôs S3 OOP system. So here I am, pretty much glued to the Advanced R and R Packages books and poking around the {tune} package (plus {yardstick} and a few others) through weeks 1 to 4 to level up my S3 OOP game.


A Turning Point
Week 5

Max and I and Hadley had a meeting, and during the meeting, Hadley (Hadley Wickham) said, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs do S7 OOP.‚Äù üò± (The face screaming in fear emoji because I am thrilled and frightened ‚Äî thrilled to meet him, but scared I won‚Äôt live up to the expectations!)
Prepare for CRAN submission



CRAN Horror Story & Dual (Muli) Branches
Week 6

‚ÄúCRAN horror story‚Äù to ‚ÄúCRAN acceptance‚Äù.
The S3 branch is now on CRAN, while the S7 branch lives on as the development version.
In practice, though, I‚Äôm juggling multiple branches, as I get used to merging, resolving merge conflicts, and navigating real-world Git and GitHub workflows.



The Great S7 Migration
Week 5-8

Implement S7 for all scoring methods
Write S7 tests for all scoring methods
Refactor code using S7 (Max led the way!)
Refactor tests accordingly



Write, Write, and Write‚Ä¶
Week 9

Write, write, and write, (but not the dissertation kind!)

Though the work is remote, I had the pleasure of meeting the other intern, Jules (Jules Walzer-Goldfeld), as well as other developers and engineers based in Europe and across the US. The most fun, though initially intimidating, has been the tidyteam meeting, where the tidyverse, tidymodels, and r-lib teams all gather on Zoom once a month.
